posts.raw_content:
Popular culture and media has massively distorted the Inquisition for decades. Here are things you should know about it.

1. The inquisition was a very long, ongoing thing that went on between the 12th century and lasted until the 1800s. The period where records were held was between 1480 to about 1870. It spanned all of Europe but was most intense in Spain and Portugal.

2. Between 1480 to 1870, approximately 200,000 people were interrogated, of which, about 6,000 people were executed. This is across all of Europe and over almost 400 years. Approximately 15% of people would be tortured so out of 200,000 people, about 30,000 were probably tortured.

3. The inquisition was not a finger pointing free for all akin the way the reign of terror and communist regimes were. There were effective safeguards against false accusations. Multiple people needed to accuse you of heresy. People bringing false or malicious accusations of heresy would actually be punished for it with excommunication or seizure of property.

4. Inquisitioners were actually forbidden from spilling blood during interrogations. Torture itself was not recommended. The main reason why it happened was because of local inquisitioners rather than being an order from the highest authority.

5. The methods of the inquisition were actually put under a lot of scrutiny with harsh criticisms being published by scholars during the time period that it was occurring in. These criticisms resulted in the inquisition gradually becoming gentler and less severe over time.

6. Most of the modern image of the inquisition comes from second wave feminist scholars who claimed hundreds of thousands or even millions of people, primarily women, were killed by the inquisition. One scholar even claimed 9 million people were killed by the inquisition but further research found it was actually only 6,000. They tied the inquisition to the witch trials even though witch trials were mostly performed by local secular authorities… Not by the church, which did indeed start the inquisition.

Conclusion? Don’t listen to pop culture representations of the Middle Ages. Pop culture has a completely fictionalized vision of what the Middle Ages were like based primarily on anti Christian fervor and a determination to pretend like Christianity engaged in mass brutality in the name of Christ when in reality… Christians have always tried to minimize bloodshed as much as possible. The non-religious on the other hand, did not have the same restraint. They deliberately wanted to murder as many people as they could during the reign of terror and under the communist regimes of Russia, China, Korea, and Cambodia. They want to act like we were the same when we had power. We were not. Do not forget that.
posts.author: MAGA9428
posts.title: Things everybody should know about the Inquisition…
posts.content:
Popular culture and media has massively distorted the Inquisition for decades. Here are things you should know about it.

  1. The inquisition was a very long, ongoing thing that went on between the 12th century and lasted until the 1800s. The period where records were held was between 1480 to about 1870. It spanned all of Europe but was most intense in Spain and Portugal.

  2. Between 1480 to 1870, approximately 200,000 people were interrogated, of which, about 6,000 people were executed. This is across all of Europe and over almost 400 years. Approximately 15% of people would be tortured so out of 200,000 people, about 30,000 were probably tortured.

  3. The inquisition was not a finger pointing free for all akin the way the reign of terror and communist regimes were. There were effective safeguards against false accusations. Multiple people needed to accuse you of heresy. People bringing false or malicious accusations of heresy would actually be punished for it with excommunication or seizure of property.

  4. Inquisitioners were actually forbidden from spilling blood during interrogations. Torture itself was not recommended. The main reason why it happened was because of local inquisitioners rather than being an order from the highest authority.

  5. The methods of the inquisition were actually put under a lot of scrutiny with harsh criticisms being published by scholars during the time period that it was occurring in. These criticisms resulted in the inquisition gradually becoming gentler and less severe over time.

  6. Most of the modern image of the inquisition comes from second wave feminist scholars who claimed hundreds of thousands or even millions of people, primarily women, were killed by the inquisition. One scholar even claimed 9 million people were killed by the inquisition but further research found it was actually only 6,000. They tied the inquisition to the witch trials even though witch trials were mostly performed by local secular authorities… Not by the church, which did indeed start the inquisition.

Conclusion? Don’t listen to pop culture representations of the Middle Ages. Pop culture has a completely fictionalized vision of what the Middle Ages were like based primarily on anti Christian fervor and a determination to pretend like Christianity engaged in mass brutality in the name of Christ when in reality… Christians have always tried to minimize bloodshed as much as possible. The non-religious on the other hand, did not have the same restraint. They deliberately wanted to murder as many people as they could during the reign of terror and under the communist regimes of Russia, China, Korea, and Cambodia. They want to act like we were the same when we had power. We were not. Do not forget that.

posts.title:
President Trump: "He had MS13 tattooed on his knuckles." 

ABC: "He had some tattoos that are interpreted that way." 

Trump: "It says MS13."

ABC: "That was photoshopped."

Trump: "Do you want me to show you the picture?"

ABC: "I'm not an expert."

twitter.content: Remember when Trump sued ABC for slander and secured a $15 million payout? Well, Trump just closed out his 100th day in office by murdering an ABC stooge on primetime TV.
